data.text:
There are countless places in the world that I dream of reaching.

Cities I really want to visit.

Intriguing historical sites.

If there's one thing I really like to learn, it's about other cultures. Different from the one I live in.

One of the places that surveys me is the huge Buddha of the city of Leshan, in China.

How did they manage to carve this giant statue into a rock?

The Buddha is located east of Shan City, Sichuan Province (China), where three rivers converge: the Min River, the Qingi River and the Dado River.

The statue is the most famous landmark of interest in the city.

In December 1996, the Buddha site was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List.

Starting in 713 during the Tang dynasty and ending in 803, it took more than ninety years to carve this statue.

During these years, thousands of employees invested their efforts and wisdom in the project.

The Giant Buddha, considered the largest Buddha carved in the world, is mentioned in poems, poems and stories.

In front of the river, buddha has a stable buddha and a symmetrical appearance that has been wonderfully captured in their festive silence. He is 71 meters high (about 233 feet) and his fingers are 8.3 meters long. The foot 9 meters wide (about 30 meters) is large enough to accommodate 100 people, and its shoulders are 24 meters wide (about 79 meters) wide enough to accommodate a basketball court.

As an architect, I'm always thrilled with the architecture of antiquity. The same luxury buildings that UNESCO cares about preserving, and recognizing. Not just for the environment in which they were built and harvested. It's, first and foremost, for all of us. That we humans will recognize. We'll teach them. We'll appreciate them. And most importantly, we will keep them, for the benefit of those who follow us.

Unfortunately, as technology advances, we lose the beauty of traditional architecture, and ancient construction methods. Therefore, it is important to document and preserve them in every country and region.
